array.string: "Border Ruffians" from Missouri invade Kansas and force election of a pro-slavery legislature.
South Carolina is the first state to secede from the United States
Delaware votes not to secede from the United States.
Mississippi becomes the second state to secede from the Union.
Florida secedes from the United States.
Georgia joins South Carolina, Florida, Mississippi, and Alabama in secession.
Jefferson Davis resigns from the United States Senate.
Texas secedes from the United States.
In Montgomery, Alabama the Confederate States of America is formed.
Jefferson Davis is elected the Provisional President of the Confederate States.
United States House passes a resolution guaranteeing noninterference with slavery.
The Constitution of the Confederate States of America is adopted.
Confederate forces fire on Fort Sumter, in the harbor of Charleston, South Carolina.
Fort Sumter surrenders to rebel forces.
Robert E. Lee resigns his commission in the United States Army.
Maryland's House of Delegates votes not to secede from the Union.
Richmond, Virginia, is named the capital of the Confederate States of America.
Queen Victoria of Britain issues a "proclamation of neutrality".
The state of Kentucky proclaims its neutrality.
At Manassas Junction, Virginia, the first major battle of the war begins.
Congress states that the war is being fought to preserve the Union and not to end slavery.
The United States government issues the first income tax.
Jefferson Davis is elected president of the Confederate States of America.
The Confederacy suffers its first significant defeat: Battle of Mill Springs.
Ulysses S. Grant gives the US its first victory of the war, by capturing Fort Henry
General Ulysses S. Grant captures Fort Donelson, Tennessee.
Union forces led by General Curtis defeat Confederate troops in Arkansas.
The iron-clad CSS Virginia is launched at Hampton Roads, Virginia.
The first battle between two ironclad warships.
The U.S. forbids all Union army officers from returning fugitive slaves.
In New Mexico, Union forces succeed in stopping the Confederate invasion.
Union Army defeat the Confederates near Shiloh, Tennessee.
New Orleans falls to Union forces under Admiral David Farragut.
Confederate troops evacuate Fort Pillow on the Mississippi River.
Battle of Memphis - Union forces capture Memphis, Tennessee, from the Confederates.
The Battle of Malvern Hill takes place.
David G. Farragut becomes the first United States Navy rear admiral.
Henry W. Halleck takes command of the Union Army.
The Confederate ironclad CSS Arkansas is scuttled on the Mississippi River.
President Lincoln restores Union General McClellan to full command.
General Robert E. Lee leads 55,000 men across the Potomac River.
Confederate forces capture Harpers Ferry, Virginia.
George McClellan halts the northward drive of Robert E. Lee's.
Abraham Lincoln removes George McClellan as commander of the Union Army.
President Lincoln approves plan to capture Richmond, Virginia, leading to the Battle of Fredericksburg.
At the Battle of Fredericksburg, Confederates defeat the Union troops.
The Emancipation Proclamation takes effect in Confederate territory.
General McClernand and Admiral Dixon Porter capture the Arkansas River for the Union.
Massachusetts Governor receives permission to raise a militia for men of African descent.
Troops under Union Colonel Benjamin Grierson attack central Mississippi.
Battle of Chancellorsville . The battle ends with a Union retreat.
The Battle of Chancellorsville ends, with a defeat of the Army of the Potomac.
Union forces begin to lay siege to the Confederate-controlled Port Hudson, Louisiana.
The first African American regiment, leaves Boston, to fight for the Union.
A Union garrison is defeated by the Army of Northern Virginia in the Shenandoah Valley town of Winchester, Virginia.
The Union wins the battle of Gettysburg.
Vicksburg, Mississippi surrenders to Ulysses S. Grant after 47 days of siege.
The first formal African American military unsuccessfully assaults Confederate-held Fort Wagner.
At Salineville, Ohio, Confederate cavalry leader John Hunt Morgan is captured by Union forces.
General Robert E. Lee sends a letter of resignation to Confederate President Jefferson Davis (which is refused upon receipt).
In Charleston, South Carolina, Union batteries and ships bombard Confederate-held Fort Sumter.
Confederates evacuate Battery Wagner and Morris Island in South Carolina.
The Union Army enters Chattanooga, Tennessee.
Battle of Bristol Station - Confederate General Robert E. Lee forces fail to drive the Union Army out of Virginia.
Battle of Wauhatchie - Forces under Union General Ulysses S. Grant ward-off a Confederate attack
Battle of Campbell's Station near Knoxville, Tennessee. Confederate troops unsuccessfully attack Union forces.
Siege of Knoxville begins - Confederate forces led by General James Longstreet place Knoxville, Tennessee under siege.
Battle of Chattanooga begins - Union forces led by General Ulysses S. Grant reinforce troops at Chattanooga, Tennessee and counter-attack Confederate troops.

Battle of Lookout Mountain - Near Chattanooga, Tennessee, Union forces under General Ulysses S. Grant capture Lookout Mountain and begin to break the Confederate siege of the city led by General Braxton Bragg.
Battle of Missionary Ridge - At Missionary Ridge in Tennessee, Union forces led by General Ulysses S. Grant break the Siege of Chattanooga by routing Confederate troops under General Braxton Bragg.
Confederate cavalry leader John Hunt Morgan and several of his men escape the Ohio state prison and return safely to the South.
CSS H. L. Hunley is the first submarine to engage and sink a warship, the USS Housatonic.
The first Northern prisoners arrive at the Confederate prison at Andersonville, Georgia.
Kilpatrick-Dahlgren raid fails - Plans to free 15,000 Union soldiers being held near Richmond, Virginia are thwarted.
Fort Pillow massacre -- Confederate forces under General Nathan Bedford Forrest kill most of the African American soldiers who had surrendered at Fort Pillow, Tennessee.
Battle of Plymouth begins . Confederate forces attack Plymouth, North Carolina.
The Battle of the Wilderness begins in Spotsylvania County, Virginia.
The Army of the Potomac, under General Ulysses S. Grant, breaks off from the Battle of the Wilderness and moves southwards.

Colonel Emory Upton leads a 10-regiment "Attack-in-depth" assault against the Confederate works at The Battle of Spotsylvania, which, though ultimately unsuccessful, would provide the idea for the massive assault against the Bloody Angle on May 12. Upton was wounded slightly but immediately is promoted to Brigadier general.
Battle of Spotsylvania Court House: Thousands of Union and Confederate soldiers die in "the Bloody Angle".
Battle of New Market, Virginia ? Students from the Virginia Military Institute fight alongside the Confederate Army to force Union General Franz Sigel out of the Shenandoah Valley.
Battle of Ware Bottom Church - In the Virginia Bermuda Hundred Campaign, 10,000 troops fight in this Confederate victory.
Battle of Cold Harbor - Union forces attack Confederate troops at Cold Harbor, Virginia.
Battle of Piedmont: Union forces under General David Hunter defeat a Confederate army at Piedmont, Virginia, taking nearly 1,000 prisoners.
Brice's Crossroads: Confederate troops under Nathan Bedford Forrest defeat a much larger Union force led by General Samuel D. Sturgis in Mississippi.
Battle of Cold Harbor ? General Ulysses S. Grant pulls his troops from their positions at Cold Harbor, Virginia and moves south.
Battle of Kernstown - Confederate General Jubal Early defeats Union troops led by General George Crook in an effort to keep Yankees out of the Shenandoah Valley.
Battle of Ezra Church begins - Confederate troops make a third unsuccessful attempt to drive Union forces from Atlanta, Georgia.
Confederate spy Belle Boyd is arrested by Union troops and detained at the Old Capitol Prison in Washington, DC.
Battle of the Crater - Union forces attempt to break Confederate lines by exploding a large bomb under their trenches.
Battle of Mobile Bay begins - At Mobile Bay near Mobile, Alabama, Admiral David Farragut leads a Union flotilla through Confederate defenses and seals one of the last major Southern ports.
Battle of Globe Tavern - Union forces try to cut a vital Confederate supply-line into Petersburg, Virginia, by attacking the Weldon Railroad.
Union forces led by General William T. Sherman launch an assault on Atlanta, Georgia.
Confederate General John Bell Hood evacuates Atlanta, Georgia after a four-month siege by General Sherman.
Union forces enter Atlanta, Georgia a day after the Confederate defenders flee the city.
The Battle of Chaffin's Farm is fought.
Battle of Darbytown Road (American Civil War): the Confederate forces' attempt to regain ground that had been lost around Richmond is thwarted.
Battle of Tom's Brook - Union cavalrymen in the Shenandoah Valley defeat Confederate forces at Tom's Brook, Virginia.
Battle of Westport - Union forces under General Samuel R. Curtis defeat Confederate troops led by General Sterling Price at Westport, near Kansas City.
Battle of Johnsonville - Confederate troops bombard a Union supply base and destroy millions of dollars in material.
Union General William Tecumseh Sherman burns Atlanta, Georgia and starts Sherman's March to the Sea.
Sherman's March to the Sea: Confederate General John Bell Hood invades Tennessee in an unsuccessful attempt to draw Union General William T. Sherman from Georgia.

Battle of Franklin ? The Army of Tennessee led by General John Bell Hood mounts a dramatically unsuccessful frontal assault on Union positions around Franklin, Tennessee (Hood lost six generals and almost a third of his troops).

Sherman's March to the Sea - At Waynesboro, Georgia, forces under Union General Judson Kilpatrick prevent troops led by Confederate General Joseph Wheeler from interfering with Union General William T. Sherman's campaign destroying a wide swath of the South on his march to the Atlantic Ocean from Atlanta (Union forces did suffer more than three times the Confederate casualties, however).
Sherman's March to the Sea - Major General William T. Sherman's Union Army troops reach Savannah, Georgia.
Franklin-Nashville Campaign - Battle of Nashville - Major General George H. Thomas's Union forces defeat Lieutenant General John Bell Hood's Confederate Army of Tennessee.
Confederate General Robert E. Lee becomes general-in-chief.
Columbia, South Carolina burns as Confederate forces flee from advancing Union forces.
The Confederate States of America reluctantly agrees to the use of African American troops.
The Congress of the Confederate States of America adjourns for the last time.
The Battle of Bentonville begins. By the end of the battle two days later the Confederate forces have retreated from Greenville, North Carolina.
In Virginia, Confederate forces capture Fort Stedman from the Union in a bloody battle.
Battle of Five Forks - In Petersburg, Virginia, Confederate General Robert E. Lee begins his final offensive.
Confederate President Jefferson Davis and most of his Cabinet flee the Confederate capital of Richmond, Virginia.
Union forces capture Richmond, Virginia, the capital of the Confederate States of America.
A day after Union forces capture Richmond, Virginia, U.S. President Abraham Lincoln visits the Confederate capital.
Battle of Sayler's Creek - Confederate General Robert E. Lee's Army of Northern Virginia fights its last major battle while in retreat from Richmond, Virginia.
At Appomattox, Virginia, Confederate General Robert E. Lee surrenders his 28,000 troops to Union General Ulysses S. Grant, effectively ending the American Civil War.
A day after his surrender to Union forces, Confederate General Robert E. Lee addresses his troops for the last time.
Mobile, Alabama, falls to the Union Army.
Abraham Lincoln is shot by John Wilkes Booth.
Confederate General Joseph Johnston surrenders his army to General William Tecumseh Sherman at the Bennett Place near Durham, North Carolina.
Jefferson Davis is captured by Union troops near Irwinville, Georgia.
Battle of Palmito Ranch ? In far south Texas, more than a month after Confederate General Lee's surrender, the last land battle of the Civil War ends with a Confederate victory.
Confederate General Edmund Kirby Smith, commander of the Confederate Trans-Mississippi division, is the last general of the Confederate Army to surrender, at Galveston, Texas.
At Fort Towson in Oklahoma Territory Confederate General Stand Watie surrenders the last significant rebel army.
Four conspirators in the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln were hanged.
Major Henry Wirz, the superintendent of a prison camp in Andersonville, Georgia, is hanged, becoming the only American Civil War soldier executed for war crimes.
Reconstruction: Tennessee becomes the first U.S. state to be readmitted to the Union following the American Civil War.
President Andrew Johnson officially declares the American Civil War to be ended.
Sergeant William Harvey Carney becomes the first African American to be awarded the Medal of Honor, for his heroism in the Assault on the Battery Wagner.
Karla Faye Tucker, age 38, is executed in Texas, becoming the first to be executed in Texas since the American Civil War.
The National Prisoner of War Museum is located in Andersonville, Georgia, on the site of an old American Civil War POW camp.
